title: Adapting Foundation Speech Recognition Models to Impaired Speech: A Semantic Re-chaining Approach for Personalization of German Speech
author: Niclas Pokel (Technical University of Munich), Pehuen Moure (University of Zurich and ETH Zurich), Roman Boehringer (University of Zurich and ETH Zurich), Yingqiang Gao (University of Zurich), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces methods for personalizing Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems, relevant for tasks in speech restoration and recognition, which are key areas in Haohe Liu's research.
background: The study addresses challenges in Automatic Speech Recognition for individuals with speech impairments by proposing ways to tailor existing models for better performance.
contribution: This paper introduces a lightweight pipeline for personalizing ASR models to enhance transcription quality for impaired speech, achieving significant error rate reductions.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggle with limited training data and often require complex setups for data augmentation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon those limitations by combining lightweight data collection techniques with novel algorithms for word selection and semantic reconstruction, allowing for better utilization of existing models.

key_innovation: The approach uses semantic re-chaining to synthesize coherent sentence-level utterances from isolated word recordings, making data collection more efficient and streamlining the ASR personalization process.
real_world_impact: This research could significantly improve communication for individuals with speech impairments by enhancing the functionality of existing ASR systems in everyday settings.
limitations: The work mentions limitations due to the small dataset size, which may affect the generalizability of the findings.

new_terms.semantic re-chaining: **Semantic re-chaining** is a method that constructs coherent sentence-level utterances from isolated word-level recordings to improve ASR performance.
new_terms.biphone coverage: **Biphone coverage** refers to the inclusion of all possible pairs of consecutive phonemes in speech datasets, which enhances phonetic diversity in ASR training.
